abstract.p: Jerry Reynolds letter comments on Daniel Drezner's Sept 29 Op-Ed in which Drezner asserts voters should not concentrate on 'needless hoopla' over outsourcing

block.p: Re ''Where Did All the Jobs Go? Nowhere,'' by Daniel W. Drezner (Op-Ed, Sept. 29):
Re ''Where Did All the Jobs Go? Nowhere,'' by Daniel W. Drezner (Op-Ed, Sept. 29):
Mr. Drezner says that voters shouldn't concentrate ''on needless hoopla over outsourcing.''

Let's see if we've got this right. President Bush's corporate tax breaks are supposed to provide incentives for corporations to invest in capital improvements and expansion, which should lead them to hire more workers.

According to Mr. Drezner, outsourcing jobs to other countries reduces labor costs here and therefore leads to increased productivity and profits, which, again, should lead to capital investment, expansion and hiring more American workers.
But these things aren't happening. We have seen very little capital investment, a continued anemic increase in hirings and virtually no increase in employee wages or benefits.
What we have seen, however, is a dramatic increase in corporations using their increased profits to buy up their own outstanding stock.
The Bush administration wants an ''ownership'' nation. We're seeing that all right, except the ownership has nothing to do with American working people.
